#Text=II
#Text=SOON
#Text=AFTER I GOT home that summer , I persuaded my grandparents to have their photographs taken , and one morning I went into the photographer ’s shop to arrange for sittings .

#Text=While I was waiting for him to come out of his developing-room , I walked about trying to recognize the likenesses on his walls : girls in Commencement dresses , country brides and grooms holding hands , family groups of three generations .
#Text=I noticed , in a heavy frame , one of those depressing ‘ crayon enlargements ’ often seen in farm-house parlours , the subject being a round-eyed baby in short dresses .
#Text=The photographer came out and gave a constrained , apologetic laugh .
#Text=‘ That ’s Tony Shimerda ’s baby .
#Text=You remember her ; she used to be the Harlings ’ Tony .
#Text=Too bad ! She seems proud of the baby , though ; would n’t hear to a cheap frame for the picture .
#Text=I expect her brother will be in for it Saturday . ’
#Text=I went away feeling that I must see Antonia again .
#Text=Another girl would have kept her baby out of sight , but Tony , of course , must have its picture on exhibition at the town photographer ’s , in a great gilt frame .
#Text=How like her ! I could forgive her , I told myself , if she had n’t thrown herself away on such a cheap sort of fellow .

#Text=Larry Donovan was a passenger conductor , one of those train-crew aristocrats who are always afraid that someone may ask them to put up a car-window , and who , if requested to perform such a menial service , silently point to the button that calls the porter .
#Text=Larry wore this air of official aloofness even on the street , where there were no car-windows to compromise his dignity .

#Text=At the end of his run he stepped indifferently from the train along with the passengers , his street hat on his head and his conductor ’s cap in an alligator-skin bag , went directly into the station and changed his clothes .
#Text=It was a matter of the utmost importance to him never to be seen in his blue trousers away from his train .
#Text=He was usually cold and distant with men , but with all women he had a silent , grave familiarity , a special handshake , accompanied by a significant , deliberate look .

#Text=He took women , married or single , into his confidence ; walked them up and down in the moonlight , telling them what a mistake he had made by not entering the office branch of the service , and how much better fitted he was to fill the post of General Passenger Agent in Denver than the rough-shod man who then bore that title .
#Text=His unappreciated worth was the tender secret Larry shared with his sweethearts , and he was always able to make some foolish heart ache over it .
#Text=As I drew near home that morning , I saw Mrs. Harling out in her yard , digging round her mountain-ash tree .
#Text=It was a dry summer , and she had now no boy to help her .
#Text=Charley was off in his battleship , cruising somewhere on the Caribbean sea .
#Text=I turned in at the gate it was with a feeling of pleasure that I opened and shut that gate in those days ; I liked the feel of it under my hand .
#Text=I took the spade away from Mrs. Harling , and while I loosened the earth around the tree , she sat down on the steps and talked about the oriole family that had a nest in its branches .
#Text=‘ Mrs. Harling , ’ I said presently , ‘ I wish I could find out exactly how Antonia ’s marriage fell through . ’
#Text=‘ Why do n’t you go out and see your grandfather ’s tenant , the Widow Steavens ?
#Text=She knows more about it than anybody else .
#Text=She helped Antonia get ready to be married , and she was there when Antonia came back .
#Text=She took care of her when the baby was born .
#Text=She could tell you everything .
#Text=Besides , the Widow Steavens is a good talker , and she has a remarkable memory . ’
#Text=III
#Text=ON THE FIRST OR second day of August I got a horse and cart and set out for the high country , to visit the Widow Steavens .
#Text=The wheat harvest was over , and here and there along the horizon I could see black puffs of smoke from the steam threshing-machines .
#Text=The old pasture land was now being broken up into wheatfields and cornfields , the red grass was disappearing , and the whole face of the country was changing .

#Text=There were wooden houses where the old sod dwellings used to be , and little orchards , and big red barns ; all this meant happy children , contented women , and men who saw their lives coming to a fortunate issue .

#Text=The windy springs and the blazing summers , one after another , had enriched and mellowed that flat tableland ; all the human effort that had gone into it was coming back in long , sweeping lines of fertility .
#Text=The changes seemed beautiful and harmonious to me ; it was like watching the growth of a great man or of a great idea .
#Text=I recognized every tree and sandbank and rugged draw .
#Text=I found that I remembered the conformation of the land as one remembers the modelling of human faces .
#Text=When I drew up to our old windmill , the Widow Steavens came out to meet me .
#Text=She was brown as an Indian woman , tall , and very strong .
#Text=When I was little , her massive head had always seemed to me like a Roman senator ’s .
#Text=I told her at once why I had come .
